titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Helen Maria Williams Letters, 1820 and undated RL.11571
titlestmt.author: Alice L. Poffinberger

publicationstmt.publisher: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2018-01-09 11:42:07 -0500.

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: Helen Maria Williams was a British novelist, poet, and translator of French-language works. Collection comprises four letters written by Helen Maria Williams, two to her nephew, Athanase Laurent Charles Coquerel, one to Mrs. [Joel?]Barlow, and one to an unidentified recipient. One letter contains the date 1820; the other letters are undated. Topics in the letters include Coquerel's position, her income, the health and situation of friends and family members, an unnamed woman she wishes to avoid, along with the imprisonment of James Wol[l]stonecraft and Thomas Payne's [Paine's] efforts on his behalf. Three letters are accompanied by partial or full transcription.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Helen Maria Williams was a British novelist, poet, and translator of French-language works. A religious dissenter, she was a supporter of abolitionism and of the ideals of the French Revolution; she was imprisoned in Paris during the Reign of Terror, but nonetheless spent much of the rest of her life in France.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Helen Maria Williams Letters were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a purchase in 2015.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Helen Maria Williams Letters, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Alice L. Poffinberger, January, 2018
Accessions described in this collection guide: 2015-0050-LUBMSS511, 2015-0050-LUBMSS512, 2015-0050-LUBMSS513, 2015-0050-LUBMSS514

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection comprises four letters written by Helen Maria Williams, two to her nephew, Athanase Laurent Charles Coquerel, one to Mrs. [Joel?]Barlow, and one to an unidentified recipient. One letter contains the date 1820; the other letters are undated. Topics in the letters include Coquerel's position, her income, the health and situation of friends and family members, an unnamed woman she wishes to avoid, along with the imprisonment of James Wol[l]stonecraft and Thomas Payne's [Paine's] efforts on his behalf. Three letters are accompanied by partial or full transcription.

controlaccess.corpname: Lisa Unger Baskin Collection (David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library)
Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture

did.unittitle: Helen Maria Williams to Athanase Laurent Charles Coquerel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letter topics include Coquerel's family and position, and the health and situation of other family members. Partial transcript included.

did.unittitle: Helen Maria Williams to Athanase Laurent Charles Coquerel

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topics of letter include Coquerel's position, the possibility of her coming to live with him, her income, and the health of other family members.

did.unittitle: Helen Maria Williams to Mrs. [Joel] Barlow

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topic is mainly the the imprisonment of James Wol[l]stonecraft and Thomas Payne's [Paine's] efforts on his behalf. Full transcript provided.

did.unittitle: Helen Maria Williams to unidentified recipient

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Topics include the health of the recipient, and Williams' desire to meet with her, except for the possibility of also meeting an unnamed woman she wishes to avoid. Partial transcription included.
